title: 107_hr3584
content: The Medicare+Choice Improvement and Stabilization Act of 2001 includes payment reforms for 2003, changes in reporting deadlines, demonstration projects for various plans, suspension of limitations for program reentry, and specialized plans for special needs beneficiaries. The Medicare+Choice Improvement and Stabilization Act of 2001 introduces payment reforms for 2003, including adjustments based on 100 percent of fee-for-service costs for that year. The Medicare+Choice Improvement and Stabilization Act of 2001 introduces payment reforms for 2003, including adjustments based on fee-for-service costs. Amendments include adding (C), or (D) in a section, specifying Medicare beneficiaries enrolled in a Medicare+Choice plan for 2003, and eliminating budget neutrality for years other than 2003. The Medicare+Choice Improvement and Stabilization Act of 2001 introduces payment reforms for 2003, including adjustments based on fee-for-service costs. Amendments include changing reporting deadlines, annual election periods, and delaying lock-in provisions. The Medicare+Choice Improvement and Stabilization Act of 2001 includes changes to reporting deadlines, annual election periods, and lock-in provisions for 2003. Reporting deadlines are moved to the third Monday in September, the annual election period is now from November 15 to December 31, and the lock-in provision is delayed by one year until 2002. The Medicare+Choice Improvement and Stabilization Act of 2001 amends various clauses and paragraphs by changing the year from 2002 to 2003. The effective date for these amendments is January 1, 2002. SEC. 4. AVOIDING DUPLICATIVE STATE REGULATION. Amends Section 1856(b)(3) of the Social Security Act to supersede any State law or regulation with respect to Medicare+Choice plans. Effective upon enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS FOR PREFERRED PROVIDER ORGANIZATIONS, POINT-OF-SERVICE PLANS, MSA PLANS, AND DISEASE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a demonstration program to modify payment rules for Medicare+Choice organizations, promoting the offering of preferred provider organizations, point-of-service coverage for non-participating providers, MSA plans, and disease management programs. Ten demonstration projects will be implemented, each lasting up to 3 years. Under the demonstration program, projects will promote Medicare+Choice plans by preferred provider organizations, point-of-service coverage for non-participating providers, and MSA plans. The Secretary may assume financial risk under risk-sharing arrangements and waive certain provisions of the Social Security Act for the program. Evaluation and reporting will be conducted by the Secretary. The Secretary will evaluate the impact of the demonstration program on Medicare+Choice plan enrollment in underserved areas and submit a report to Congress. The report will assess costs, savings, and may include recommendations for changes to the Medicare+Choice program. SEC. 6. SUSPENSION OF LIMITATION FOR PROGRAM REENTRY FOR 2003 AND 2004. Amends Section 1857(c)(4) of the Social Security Act to suspend limitations for contracts entered into for contract year 2003 or 2004. SEC. 7. SPECIALIZED MEDICARE+CHOICE PLANS FOR SPECIAL NEEDS BENEFICIARIES. Specialized Medicare+Choice plans for special needs beneficiaries may be any type of coordinated care plan, exclusively serving special needs beneficiaries. Special needs beneficiaries are defined as Medicare+Choice eligible individuals who are institutionalized, entitled to medical assistance under a State plan, or meet requirements determined by the Secretary. Enrollment in specialized Medicare+Choice plans for individuals with severe or disabling chronic conditions is permitted. Specialized Medicare+Choice plans can restrict enrollment to special needs beneficiaries. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must report to Congress by December 31, 2005, on the impact of these plans on cost and quality of services provided to enrollees. The amendments made by subsections (a), (b), and (c) of the Act will take effect upon enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must issue final regulations for special needs beneficiaries by September 1, 2002. Additionally, there is an extension of Municipal Health Service Demonstration Projects. The Reconciliation Act of 1985 is amended to extend the project deadline to December 31, 2009, with restrictions on the number of participants.
